articles.headline: Soldier’s Attack at Base Echoed Rampage in 2009
articles.snippet: The replay of a shooting at Fort Hood raised questions about what lessons Army officials had learned from 2009, when Maj. Nidal Malik Hasan went on a shooting spree, and how prepared they are to deal with threats from within.
articles.abstract: The replay of a shooting at Fort Hood raised questions about what lessons Army officials had learned from 2009, when Maj. Nidal Malik Hasan went on a shooting spree, and how prepared they are to deal with threats from within.
articles.lead_paragraph: KILLEEN, Tex. — In the aftermath of a deadly rampage at Fort Hood here in November 2009 that left 13 people dead, Defense Secretary Robert M. Gates announced a Pentagon review of the shooting to help ensure, he said, that “nothing like this ever happens again.”
articles.byline: By Manny Fernandez, Serge F. Kovaleski and Eric Schmitt

articles.headline: Talk of Freeing a Spy for Israel Stirs Old Unease for U.S. Jews
articles.snippet: More and more Jews say the time to free Jonathan J. Pollard is long past, but they are unsure whether he should be used as a chit in a diplomatic transaction with Israel.
articles.abstract: More and more Jews say the time to free Jonathan J. Pollard is long past, but they are unsure whether he should be used as a chit in a diplomatic transaction with Israel.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Each year, just before Passover, Malcolm Hoenlein writes a letter to President Obama requesting that he grant clemency to Jonathan J. Pollard, the American sentenced to life in prison in 1987 for passing suitcases stuffed with classified documents to Israel.

articles.headline: Anadarko Pays Billions in Settling Toxins Case
articles.snippet: The oil company agreed to pay the United States government to restore thousands of sites polluted by toxins and compensate thousands of personal-injury claimants.
articles.abstract: The oil company agreed to pay the United States government to restore thousands of sites polluted by toxins and compensate thousands of personal-injury claimants.
articles.lead_paragraph: HOUSTON — A giant Texas oil company, Anadarko Petroleum, has agreed to pay $5.1 billion for a vast environmental cleanup, a sum the Justice Department said was the largest it had ever won in such a case.

articles.headline: Mozilla’s Chief Felled by View on Gay Unions
articles.snippet: Under pressure from employees and the public for his support of a ban on gay marriage, Brendan Eich stepped down as chief executive of the company behind the Firefox browser.
articles.abstract: Under pressure from employees and the public for his support of a ban on gay marriage, Brendan Eich stepped down as chief executive of the company behind the Firefox browser.
articles.lead_paragraph: Updated | In Silicon Valley, where personal quirks and even antisocial personalities are tolerated as long as you are building new products and making money, a socially conservative viewpoint may be one trait you have to keep to yourself.
articles.byline: By Nick Bilton and Noam Cohen

articles.headline: After 3 Decades, Letterman Says He Will Sign Off
articles.snippet: David Letterman, the host of CBS’s “Late Show With David Letterman,” said he would retire when his contract ran out in 2015. Now the speculation begins on who will succeed him.
articles.abstract: David Letterman, the host of CBS’s “Late Show With David Letterman,” said he would retire when his contract ran out in 2015. Now the speculation begins on who will succeed him.
articles.lead_paragraph: David Letterman, the longest-running host in the history of late-night television, will retire from his CBS show next year, the latest shake-up in a roiling talk-show lineup.

articles.headline: Nest Labs Stops Selling Its Smoke Detector
articles.snippet: Citing concerns that its smoke and carbon monoxide detector might be unintentionally turned off, Nest Labs is halting sales of the product and disabling a feature that allows users to turn it off with a wave.
articles.abstract: Citing concerns that its smoke and carbon monoxide detector might be unintentionally turned off, Nest Labs is halting sales of the product and disabling a feature that allows users to turn it off with a wave.
articles.lead_paragraph: Nest Labs, the home automation company recently acquired by Google for $3.2 billion, said on Thursday that it was halting sales of its smoke and carbon monoxide detector over safety concerns.

articles.headline: A Village Stadium Is a Symbol of Power for Hungary’s Premier
articles.snippet: Viktor Orban, the country’s prime minister, has been aggressive both politically and in the business world, and a new soccer stadium in his tiny hometown is testament to his rising ambitions.
articles.abstract: Viktor Orban, the country’s prime minister, has been aggressive both politically and in the business world, and a new soccer stadium in his tiny hometown is testament to his rising ambitions.
articles.lead_paragraph: FELCSUT, Hungary — Something strange is going on here among the humble Soviet-era cottages.

articles.headline: G.M. Turns to Experienced Crisis Experts
articles.snippet: The creation of the team of outside advisers stands in marked contrast to General Motors’ early approach to handling the recall crisis, when it looked primarily inward to set strategy.
articles.abstract: The creation of the team of outside advisers stands in marked contrast to General Motors’ early approach to handling the recall crisis, when it looked primarily inward to set strategy.
articles.lead_paragraph: DETROIT — At the end of the second bruising day of testimony on General Motors’ ignition switch recall, Mary T. Barra was in no mood for more questions.
articles.byline: By Bill Vlasic and Hilary Stout

articles.headline: Gunman Had ‘Clean Record,’ With No Violent Sign, Officials Say
articles.snippet: Military officials said they had seen nothing to indicate that Specialist Ivan Antonio Lopez was previously violent or suicidal.
articles.abstract: Military officials said they had seen nothing to indicate that Specialist Ivan Antonio Lopez was previously violent or suicidal.
articles.lead_paragraph: Specialist Ivan Antonio Lopez had seen a military psychiatrist as recently as last month. He was being treated for depression and anxiety, and had been prescribed Ambien to help him sleep. He had come back from a four-month deployment to Iraq in 2011 and told superiors he had suffered a traumatic head injury there. But military officials said he had never seen combat, and there was no record of any combat-related injury. He was being evaluated for possible post-traumatic stress disorder.

articles.headline: Karzai Is Trying to Keep His Sway After Term Ends
articles.snippet: As Afghanistan girds for its presidential election, an exercise that President Hamid Karzai has shaped at every stage, those hoping to see him retire quietly may be disappointed.
articles.abstract: As Afghanistan girds for its presidential election, an exercise that President Hamid Karzai has shaped at every stage, those hoping to see him retire quietly may be disappointed.
articles.lead_paragraph: KABUL, Afghanistan — American officials have ignored him, and Afghanistan’s presidential contenders have tried to persuade voters that they will be different from him. But those hoping to see President Hamid Karzai slip into a quiet retirement may be disappointed in the months to come.

articles.headline: U.S. to Reassess Status of Talks on Middle East
articles.snippet: Secretary of State John Kerry said he was flying home to Washington to meet with President Obama to reassess the peace negotiations, and whether there is a path forward.
articles.abstract: Secretary of State John Kerry said he was flying home to Washington to meet with President Obama to reassess the peace negotiations, and whether there is a path forward.
articles.lead_paragraph: RABAT, Morocco — With Israel and the Palestinians falling into a familiar cycle of tit-for-tat retribution, and a peace agreement more elusive than ever, Secretary of State John Kerry conceded on Friday that this week had been a “reality check” for the peace process.
articles.byline: By Michael R. Gordon and Mark Landler

articles.headline: Covering Afghan Vote, Until Shot by an Ally
articles.snippet: Anja Niedringhaus, a Pulitzer Prize-winning photographer for The Associated Press, was attacked in eastern Afghanistan as she traveled to cover preparations for the presidential vote.
articles.abstract: Anja Niedringhaus, a Pulitzer Prize-winning photographer for The Associated Press, was attacked in eastern Afghanistan as she traveled to cover preparations for the presidential vote.
articles.lead_paragraph: KABUL, Afghanistan — For the two seasoned war correspondents, it was not an unusually risky trip. Getting out to see Afghanistan up close was what Anja Niedringhaus, a Pulitzer Prize-winning photographer for The Associated Press, and Kathy Gannon, a veteran reporter for the news agency, did best.
articles.byline: By Matthew Rosenberg and Farooq Jan Mangal

articles.headline: Hiring Rises, but Number of Jobless Stays High
articles.snippet: Better weather encouraged employers to begin hiring workers more aggressively in March, adding 192,000 to payrolls. The jobless rate remained flat 6.7 percent.
articles.abstract: Better weather encouraged employers to begin hiring workers more aggressively in March, adding 192,000 to payrolls. The jobless rate remained flat 6.7 percent.
articles.lead_paragraph: Employers are hiring at a more aggressive pace again after a winter cold snap, but the pace of job gains is only slowly making up for years of lost ground in the labor market.

articles.headline: Appealing to a College for More Financial Aid
articles.snippet: Some strategies can help win more money for your child, but it depends on the institution.
articles.abstract: Some strategies can help win more money for your child, but it depends on the institution.
articles.lead_paragraph: The era of the financial aid appeal has arrived in full, and April is the month when much of the action happens.
